'Class 10' is a term indicating that the read/write speeds of a card is more than 10mb per second. In real-world tests, I've consistently gotten 12-15 mb/s on large file transfers, and 9-10 mb/s on transfers of multiple small files. Unfortunately, you can't put this SD card in the same league as the high end class 10 cards that hit 25+ mb/s, but unless you are recording HD video or some other intensive data reading/writing, speeds beyond this class 10 card aren't really necessary.I have been using this SD card for video recording, file transfers, file storage, and whatever else I have been able to throw at it, and have not run into issues. column697:
My camera uses SD cards and the duration of continuous shooting (i.e. the number of photos at the shortest interval, fastest speed) is highly dependent on the speed of the SD disk I use.  The disk is responsible for clearing the on-camera cache of my dSLR, and my experience with cards like SanDisks Class 10 cards is that they allow me to take a nearly continuous stream of raw, 14 MP images without overloading the cache and write speed of the camera.However, the class ratings of SD cards is something that is known to vary despite the attempt at keeping the class weight ratings.  This is often related to differences in write vs. read capabilities of the cards.  Thus, it becomes tricky to find a good card or the true high performance cards.  This is probably more so if you are using a video camera or other more intense speed device and may be less of an issue if you are generally reading off a card as you might do in an MP3 player, etc.This brings us to the Amazon branded cards.  With my dSLR (Pentax K5), I'm finding that the card(s), I have 3 of these now (1 8GB and 2 16GB), and they all perform as fast as any of my fastest cards without any noticeable issues.  They seem to perform better than cards I've obtained by Patriot or Transcend and as good as ones I have from Kingston and SanDisk.Would I pay more for them than other brands?  I doubt it.  Digital cameras, generally are not that intense with these cards.  I have Kingston class 6 cards that are comparable to these.  I also have my suspicions that most of the SD cards out there are probably produced by a limited number of producers and rebranded for sale.  These Amazon cards are almost definitely in that category.  As a result chances are they'll never be better than any specific brand or product, but they'll almost certainly always be as good.Last, the results you get will likely vary based on the product you are using your SD card in, the primary purpose of the SD card (reading vs. writing), and how much wear and tear your card takes.  To step back a bit, I rarely use video or continuous shooting with my camera.  In my typical shoot one photo at a time regime, any SD card works as well as any other, especially if you stick to those brands that are the most purchased.  Only once have I had a SD card fall apart, and while I could blame the manufacturer, it could just as well been something I did.  Amazon's cards seem to be as good as any of those brands I've purchased before, and they are a brand that is known to stand behind their products."

column870: Is this for point and shoot or DSLR?
column871:
I just opened 1 of 3 new 16GB amazon.com SDHC cards.  The content sheet in the package states 'Amazonbasics SDHC card will be the best match with your point and shoot camera ...'.  Why not state digital camera?  Why exlude DSLR?  The listing states 'Continuous photo shoot, suited for DSLR or digital cameras.'  No mention of DSLR. I'll update my review after use.  Maybe someone from amazon will read this and provide the clarification?Appended:Still concerned so I decided to so some simple benchmarking. Using my desktop's internal SD card reader (I don't know its speed capability), I tested 3 cards, amazon.com 16GB Class 10, 4GB Sandisk Extreme Class 10, 8GB Sandisk Ultra Class 4.I copied 252MB of image files to each of three cards:amazon.com - 68 seconds or 3.7mbsSD Extreme - 18 seconds or 14.0mbsSD Ultra - 53 seonds or 4.75mbsI then realized that I formated the amazon.com as NTFS in the computer and the other two were formated in a Nikon D7000, so I formated the amazon.com card in the D7000 and retestedamazon.com - 29 seconds or 8.7mbsrepeated the tests and the results were nearly identical.amazon.com card faster than the Sandisk class 4, but does not match the speed of the Sandisk class 10.To test write speeds, I loaded the cards in my D7000 and held the shutter. The D7000 is rated at 6fps.The Sandisk Extreme did 22 frames before a buffering delay kicked in. The amazon.com and the Sandisk Ultra both did 17 frames before a buffering delay kicked in.I would still like to know why DSLR was left off the printed material. amazon?"

The official speed ratings are linear in that class 10 is 10x the base speed, so for example, a class 2 card reads/writes at 2MB/s and a class 10 reads/writes at 10MB/s.  So if you are using an old class 2 or 4 card with a new camera, it's going to take a relatively long time to store a photo - with a 10-14 megapixel camera (depending on what compression level you use) a photo file might be 2-6MB in size; that could be several seconds to store on an old card or under a second with a class 10."

column1101: 4GB card only: good speed but low storage
column1102:
Please note that this review is for the 4GB SDHC card only which is the ONLY 'class 10' card of this bunch. The 8/16/32GB cards are all 'class 4' cards, therefore a lot slower.Quick Overview:- Capacity - 4GB- Type - SDHC- Speed - 10 MByte/s (or 80 Mbit/s which would translate to a 66x rating)- Physical Size - standard or '32 mm x 24 mm x 2.1 mm'The small capacity make it a candidate for picture frames, older cameras and possibly for a DSi. The good speed rating should make it acceptable to use with compatible cameras and camcorders.The card gets 3 stars (means 'it's Okay') because the price is not exactly a bargain and because 4GB is really small in this day and age. The speed rating and the excellent Amazon service for the AmazonBasics line (easy to return, warranty service) are pluses.Notes of Caution:- This is an SDHC (with the HC underlined) card. Which means that some older devices may not support it even if it fits into the slot. You are safe if your gadget specifically specifies support for SDHC (as opposed to SD only). If not, it could still work but it's a gamble.- Make sure that this is the correct physical size before you order. SDHC cards also come in 'mini' and 'micro' sizes. While the 'micro' cards are easy to recognize because they are VERY small, the 'regular' (24 mm wide) and the 'mini' (20 mm wide) can be easily confused.- In addition, some old cameras may not recognize memory above 2GB and will format the card to use 2GB only.- Amazon lumped together reviews for AmazonBasics SDHC cards of several capacities. Be aware the 4GB is the ONLY one that is 'class 10'. All the other cards are 'class 4' at the time I'm writing this, meaning that they are a lot slower:  Class 4 = 32 Mbit/second vs. Class 10 = 80 Mbit/s."

column1242: Used it as extra RAM in my Windows 7 laptop
column1243:
I recently started working at a new company and I received a brand new Dell laptop running Windows 7 (32 bit edition).As a designer, I'm in and out of Photoshop all day, and as you might know, Photoshop is one of the most RAM intensive programs you can add to a PC.  Well, I was out of luck, because Windows 7 (32 bit edition) can only recognize 4GB of RAM (3.2 usable) regardless of how much you install.  So, when I'm running Photoshop alongside other programs like Outlook or Google Chrome, things slow down... a lot.Now, there a bunch of tweaks you can make to Photoshop to make it less memory hungry, but that's just like telling someone to walk slower on their broken leg.  The other option was to reformat the computer (wiping out all of my programs/settings) and install the 64 bit version of Windows 7.Fortunately, Windows 7 has a little-known feature called ReadyBoost.  It allows you to dedicate a hard drive (up to 4GB - 8GB) as extra memory in case you run out of RAM.Since this SD Card is pretty fast (Class 10), I gave it a try and I immediately noticed a difference in Photoshop.  It opens faster, I can zoom without the picture stuttering, and it is generally smoother all over.  All I had to do is put the card into the laptop's SD card slot, go to MY COMPUTER, right click on SDCARD, and click on the 'Dedicate to ReadyBoost' tab that comes up.  That's it.  When the RAM would normally overflow onto the slower internal hard drive, it uses the SD Card as a solid state scratch drive instead.For the price, it was well worth the experiment and I'm very pleased with the results."
